content.title: Hodgkin Lymphoma
content.summary: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is a B-cell lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells (large binucleated cells with prominent nucleoli, 'owl's eye' appearance) in a reactive inflammatory background. It typically presents in young adults with painless lymphadenopathy and is one of the most curable cancers, with >85% long-term survival using ABVD chemotherapy and/or radiation.
key_points: Reed-Sternberg cells are diagnostic but comprise <1% of tumor mass
Bimodal age distribution: peak 15-35 and >55 years
Presents with painless lymphadenopathy, often cervical/mediastinal
B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss) have prognostic significance
ABVD (doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine) is standard therapy
PET-adapted therapy reduces treatment in early-stage disease
content.statement: Hodgkin lymphoma is a highly curable B-cell lymphoma defined by Reed-Sternberg cells in an inflammatory milieu, staged by Ann Arbor system, and treated with chemotherapy ± radiation therapy with excellent cure rates.

explanation.intuition: HL is like finding a criminal (Reed-Sternberg cell) hiding in a crowd (inflammatory infiltrate). The criminal is rare (<1% of cells) but the whole crowd is the tumor. The inflammatory cells aren't innocent bystanders - they're recruited by the RS cells and help them survive. Killing the criminal (RS cell) disperses the crowd and cures the disease.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike most cancers, the neoplastic cells (RS cells) are rare and the tumor mass is mostly reactive immune cells. RS cells evade immune destruction by expressing PD-L1 and secreting immunosuppressive cytokines. This makes HL highly sensitive to checkpoint inhibitors.
explanation.technical_details: Classic HL RS cells are CD15+, CD30+, PAX5 weak, CD20-, CD45-. They arise from germinal center B cells that have undergone 'crippling mutations' in immunoglobulin genes but escape apoptosis through NF-κB activation, often driven by EBV (30-40% of cases). Nodular lymphocyte-predominant HL (NLPHL) has different biology (CD20+ 'popcorn cells').

definitions_glossary.Reed_Sternberg_cell: Large binucleated cell with prominent nucleoli; pathognomonic for classic HL
definitions_glossary.owl_eye_appearance: Classic RS cell morphology with mirror-image nuclei and prominent nucleoli
definitions_glossary.CD30: Surface marker expressed by RS cells; target of brentuximab vedotin
definitions_glossary.CD15: Surface marker expressed by RS cells; characteristic immunophenotype
definitions_glossary.B_symptoms: Fever >38°C, night sweats, weight loss >10% in 6 months
definitions_glossary.Ann_Arbor_staging: Staging system based on number of involved lymph node regions and presence of extranodal disease
definitions_glossary.BEACOPP: Intensified regimen for advanced HL; higher cure rate but more toxicity
definitions_glossary.contiguity: HL spreads by contiguous lymph node regions unlike NHL
definitions_glossary.nodular_sclerosis: Most common HL subtype; lacunar cells and collagen bands
definitions_glossary.EBV_association: Epstein-Barr virus detected in 30-40% of classic HL; may drive RS cell survival
definitions_glossary.mediastinal_mass: Common presentation of HL; may cause superior vena cava syndrome

pathophysiology.cell_of_origin: Germinal center B cell with crippled immunoglobulin genes
pathophysiology.mechanism: RS cells escape apoptosis through NF-κB activation, recruit inflammatory cells via cytokines
pathophysiology.EBV_role: Present in 30-40% of cases; LMP1 mimics CD40 signaling, activates NF-κB
pathophysiology.immune_evasion: PD-L1 overexpression, Th2 cytokine environment, Treg recruitment

classic_HL_subtypes.nodular_sclerosis: 70%; young adults, mediastinal involvement, lacunar cells
classic_HL_subtypes.mixed_cellularity: 20-25%; older adults, more EBV+, frequent B symptoms

clinical_presentation: Alcohol-induced lymph node pain (rare but classic)

Ann_Arbor_system.stage_II: ≥2 lymph node regions, same side of diaphragm
Ann_Arbor_system.stage_IV: Extranodal organ involvement (liver, bone marrow, lung)

workup: Bone marrow biopsy (rarely needed if PET-CT negative)

differential_diagnosis: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (especially primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma)

early_stage_favorable.PET_adapted: If PET-negative after 2 cycles, may omit radiation

advanced_stage.PET_adapted: Escalate or de-escalate based on interim PET

definition.@value: A B-cell lymphoma characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells in a reactive inflammatory background, presenting with lymphadenopathy and highly curable with chemotherapy and radiation therapy

scopeNote.@value: Includes classic HL (4 subtypes) and nodular lymphocyte-predominant HL

learning_objectives: Describe Reed-Sternberg cell morphology and immunophenotype
Apply Ann Arbor staging system with modifiers
Identify treatment options for relapsed/refractory disease
clinical_pearls: Reed-Sternberg cells are CD30+, CD15+, CD20-, CD45- in classic HL
Contiguous spread is characteristic of HL (unlike NHL)
NLPHL is CD20+ and treated differently than classic HL
PET-CT is essential for staging and response assessment
Checkpoint inhibitors have transformed relapsed HL (PD-L1 amplification)
Long-term survivors need monitoring for secondary malignancies
common_misconceptions: RS cells comprise majority of tumor - they're <1% of cells
All HL is the same - NLPHL has different biology and treatment
Bleomycin pulmonary toxicity is dose-dependent - also idiosyncratic
